questions.text: What is the most common site for a thyroglossal cyst?

choices.text: At the level of the hyoid

questions.solution:
The most common site for thyroglossal cyst is infrahyoid region.

It can occur anywhere along the migratory course of the duct:

  • Infrahyoid (most common site)
  • Region of thyroid cartilage
  • Suprahyoid
  • Floor of mouth
  • Beneath foramen caecum

 

A thyroglossal duct cyst is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood. Normally, the thyroglossal duct regresses once the thyroid gland has completely descended. If it fails to regress, a thyroglossal duct cyst is formed.

It can be differentiated from other midline neck swellings by the following features: 

  • Can be moved sideways but not vertically
  • Moves with both deglutition and tongue protrusion

Surgical management of a thyroglossal cyst is via Sistrunk procedure.

Note: Presence of thyroid in the midline posterior 1/3rd of tongue is called lingual thyroid. It is due to failure of descent of the thyroglossal duct during development.

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with neck swelling which moves with deglutition as shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A thyroglossal cyst is the only midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition. This is because the thyroid gland is fixed to the hyoid. 

Thyroglossal duct cyst:

It is a congenital midline neck swelling that typically presents during childhood often noticed after an upper respiratory infection. It represents the persistence of the track of the thyroid gland and can be found adjacent to the midline. The thyroid gland descends early in fetal life from the base of the tongue towards its position in the lower neck. At the time of descent, the hyoid bone has not been formed and the track of the thyroid gland is variable, passing in front, through, or behind the eventual position of the hyoid body. 

Clinical features of thyroglossal cyst:

  • Classically the cyst moves upwards on swallowing and on tongue protrusion. This indicates attachment to the hyoid bone. 
  • Swelling is smooth, soft, fluctuant (cystic), nontender, mobile, often transilluminant.
  • Thyroid fossa is empty, if there is no thyroid in the normal location.

Complications of thyroglossal cyst:

  • The most common complication is infection.
  • Thyroglossal fistula is an acquired condition that either follows infection of the cyst which bursts open or due to inadequate removal of the cyst.
  • 1% of thyroglossal duct cysts are found to be malignant of which the most common type of cancer is papillary (85%).
Neck swellings that move with deglutition are:
  • Thyroid swellings
  • Subhyoid bursitis 
  • Dermoid cysts attached to the hyoid bone

However, only the thyroglossal cyst moves with tongue protrusion. This is because the duct extends from the foramen caecum of the tongue to the isthmus of the gland. 

Sistrunk’s operation is performed to excise the cyst and prevent a recurrence. It involves the excision of the whole thyroglossal tract, involving removal of the body of the hyoid bone, and suprahyoid tract through the tongue base to the vallecula at the site of the primitive foramen caecum along with the core of tissue on either side.

questions.text: A child with a midline swelling on the neck is being prepared for a Sistrunk procedure. Along with en bloc cystectomy, which of the following structures will be resected?

choices.text: Thyroglossal tract and part of thyroid
Central hyoid bone and thyroglossal tract
Thyroglossal tract and associated cervical lymph nodes

questions.solution:
Sistrunk operation involves en bloc cystectomy with excision of the entire thyroglossal tract till the base of the tongue along with the central hyoid bone.

It is the procedure of choice for the surgical management of thyroglossal duct cysts. It is done to prevent recurrence and malignant transformation. 

The most common malignancy in thyroglossal cysts is papillary thyroid carcinoma. In such a case, Sistrunk operation with total thyroidectomy is considered.

questions.text: A patient with a nodule of the neck presents to the surgery OPD. A junior resident performs the following method to palpate it. Identify the procedure shown in the video below.
questions.solution:
The video depicts Lahey’s method of palpation of the left lobe of the thyroid gland.

In Lahey's method, for palpating the left lobe, the examiner initially pushes the right lobe medially with the left hand, and then using the right hand, the border and consistency of the left lobe is palpated.

Other options:

Option B: In Crile's method the patient is asked to swallow, while the examiner palpates the gland with the thumb. This gives a clear indication regarding the slight enlargement of the thyroid gland or small nodules.

Option C: Kocher's method is done to demonstrate the pressure effect of the thyroid gland on the trachea or larynx. Lateral compression will result in stridor.

Option D: Pemberton's sign (not method), is engorgement of neck veins when the patient is asked to raise their hands above the head and the arms should touch the ears. It is seen in patients with retrosternal goiter.

questions.text: A patient with a solitary, 2x3 cm, nodular thyroid swelling came to your clinic with a recent report that showed elevated T4 and normal TSH levels.  What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ultrasonography is the next best step in the evaluation of a euthyroid (normal TSH) patient with a solitary thyroid nodule. USG is a non-invasive and inexpensive way to stratify the risk of the nodule into benign or malignant tissue.

Benign nodules are easily compressible and can be seen to deform by applying pressure with the probe while performing USG. Malignant nodules tend to be hard and firm. 

Ultrasound findings of a nodule that are considered suspicious of malignancy include:

  • Microcalcifications
  • Hypervascularity
  • Infiltrative margins
  • Hypoechoic compared with surrounding parenchyma

questions.text: FNAC report of a patient with discrete thyroid swelling shows a Thy2 lesion. What do you infer from this report?
questions.solution:
FNAC report of Thy2 indicates a non-neoplastic lesion.

questions.text: A 22-year-old student with a nodular thyroid swelling undergoes a radionuclide scan. What is the risk of malignancy of the pathology given below?
questions.solution:
The pathology on the scan shows decreased iodine uptake by a cold thyroid nodule. It is associated with around 20% risk of malignancy.

A thyroid scan is used in patients with hyperthyroidism with low or normal TSH.

Hot nodules indicate increased function of the gland and are rarely malignant. They are managed with either I131 or surgery. The risk of malignancy is higher with “cold” lesions (15-20%) as compared to “warm” lesions (<5%).

Cold nodules need to be further evaluated using USG as they pose a higher risk of malignancy.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a discrete thyroid swelling. USG reveals an isolated cystic swelling of the gland. Which of the following statements correctly expresses the risk of malignancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Isolated cystic swellings are malignant in 24% of males.

The general rule of thumb is that the risk of malignancy is greater in:

  • Isolated > dominant swellings
  • Solid > cystic
  • Men > women

The risk of malignancy in thyroid swellings, given by the rule of twelve, is depicted below. The risk of cancer in thyroid swelling can be expressed as a factor of 12.

questions.text: A patient presents with a painless swelling of the neck. The histology of the tissue is as given in the image below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The slide shows the histopathology of Hashimoto thyroiditis, with:

  • Follicular destruction
  • Reduced colloid with increased interstitial connective tissue
  • Small lymphocyte and plasma cell infiltration
  • A well-developed germinal centre may be seen
  • Hurthle (Askanazy) cells that have abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm lining the follicles

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is also known as struma lymphomatosa or lymphocytic thyroiditis. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure.

Clinical features:

  • Most prevalent between 45-65 years of age
  • More common in females
  • Painless enlargement of the thyroid
  • Hashitoxicosis: When the auto-antibodies attack and damage the follicles, there is a sudden release of thyroid hormones from these follicles. This leads to a transient phase of thyrotoxicosis.
  • Hypothyroidism: Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism.

Diagnosis:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid receptors
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

These patients are managed with thyroid hormone replacement therapy.

In patients with long-standing goiter, there is a risk of compressive features and the development of thyroid lymphoma. Such cases can be treated with total thyroidectomy. It may also predispose to papillary thyroid carcinoma.

Other options: 

Option A: Histological features of medullary carcinoma of the thyroid include polygonal to spindle-shaped cells in the form of nests, trabeculae or follicles. Small, round anaplastic cells may be found in some cases and amyloid deposits derived from calcitonin polypeptides are present in the stroma.

The given slide below shows medullary carcinoma of thyroid:

Option C: Grave's disease is an autoimmune disorder characterized by hyperthyroidism due to circulating autoantibodies. The thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins bind to the TSH receptors, causing overgrowth of the thyroid gland and increased thyroid hormone synthesis. Histologically, there is acinar cell hypertrophy and hyperplasia with the absence of normal colloid in the tall columnar epithelium (normally the epithelium is flat with colloid). Lymphoid infiltrates, consisting predominantly of T cells, along with scattered B cells and mature plasma cells, are present throughout the interstitium. Germinal centers are common.

The given slide below shows Grave's disease:

questions.text: A middle-aged female patient presented with malaise, fever, and painful neck swelling. She had recently recovered from an episode of upper respiratory tract infection.  Lab reports show slightly elevated T4 and ESR was 100 mm/hr. What is the most appropriate management option for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of De Quervain's thyroiditis for which NSAIDs is the treatment of choice. In this condition, T3, T4 and thyroglobulin may be raised due to the release of preformed hormones from the destructed follicles. 

De Quervain’s thyroiditis (subacute or viral thyroiditis) is a granulomatous enlargement of the thyroid gland, usually following a viral infection. It is an inflammatory condition and not an infection as the thyroid gland is inherently resistant to infection due to its extensive blood and lymphatic supply, high iodide content, and fibrous capsule.  

It predominantly occurs in women between the ages of 30-40 years. The condition is self-limiting, and management is symptomatic i.e. aspirin and other non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs are used for pain relief, but steroids may be indicated in more severe cases.

Note: Acute suppurative thyroiditis mimics De Quervain’s thyroiditis in that it is often preceded by a pyogenic upper respiratory tract infection or otitis media. However, acute suppurative thyroiditis is more common in children.

questions.text: A 45-year-old lady, with a painless neck swelling, presented with palpitations and weight loss. Thyroid function tests revealed elevated T3 and T4, low TSH, and negative TSH-R Ab. Iodine scan showed multiple thyroid nodules with increased iodine uptake. Initial anti-thyroid treatment was given. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of toxic multinodular goitre. The next step of management once a euthyroid state is achieved is a near-total thyroidectomy.

Toxic nodular goiters are often large, uncomfortable, and are prone to recurrence. In a developing country like India, a near-total thyroidectomy eliminates the risk of recurrence and simplifies follow-up. However, it causes immediate thyroid failure and necessitates lifelong thyroxine replacement. 

Option A: Toxic multinodular goitres may show a decreased response to antithyroid drugs or may even enlarge further. Therefore, surgical management is recommended. 

Option B: Sub-total thyroidectomy has chances of recurrence and hence cannot be a definitive therapy.

Option C: Large goiters show decreased response to radioactive iodine and the chances of recurrence are also high.

questions.text: What will be the most likely associated condition with increased TSH and low T4 levels?
questions.solution:
Increased TSH and low T4 levels are seen in primary hypothyroidism. Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the only cause of primary hypothyroidism in the given options. 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual & progressive thyroid failure. It is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. They also have autoantibodies against thyroid receptors, thyroid peroxidase and thyroglobulin. 

Other options:

Option A: Hypoparathyroidism is generally not associated with hypothyroidism, except in certain congenital multisystem disorders such as DiGeorge's syndrome.

Option C: Grave's disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. It is an autoimmune disorder caused due to autoantibodies against the TSH receptor. There will be elevated T3 and T4 levels with low TSH levels. 

Option B: A TSH-producing pituitary adenoma can have increased TSH levels, but there will be elevated T3, T4 levels as well.

questions.text: A 50-year-old hypothyroid female patient presents with a painless, hard anterior neck mass, which progresses over weeks to years associated with dysphagia. Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to the surrounding tissues. Which of the following investigations will confirm the provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Riedel’s thyroiditis,  which is confirmed by an open thyroid biopsy.

FNAC is inadequate due to the firm and fibrous nature of the gland.

Riedel’s thyroiditis is invasive autoimmune fibrous thyroiditis where thyroid gland tissue is replaced by fibrous tissue. It is an IgG4-related systemic disease characterized by:

  • Elevated serum IgG4 levels
  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltrate
  • Abundance of IgG4 bearing plasma cells

It is associated with other focal sclerosing syndromes including mediastinal, retroperitoneal, periorbital, retro-orbital fibrosis, and sclerosing cholangitis.

Clinical features:

  • Occurs predominantly in women between 30-60 years
  • Painless, hard anterior neck mass
  • Progresses over weeks to years to produce symptoms of compression:
    • Dysphagia
    • Dyspnea
    • Choking
    • Hoarseness
  • Symptoms of hypothyroidism and hypoparathyroidism as the gland is replaced by fibrous tissue
  • Physical examination reveals a hard, “woody” thyroid gland with fixation to surrounding tissues

Treatment includes surgery, high-dose steroids, tamoxifen, and thyroxine replacement.

questions.text: The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via:
questions.solution:
The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck and the most common type of goitre approached is the secondary retrosternal goiter.

A goiter is considered to be retrosternal if at least 50% of the thyroid tissue is located intrathoracically. They can be primary or secondary.

  Primary retrosternal goiter Secondary retrosternal goiter
Occurrence 1%  Majority of retrosternal goiters 
Origin

Arise from ectopic thyroid tissue in the chest

No connection with the thyroid tissue in the neck

 Arise from the downward extension of cervical thyroid tissue along the fascial planes of the neck
Blood supply Intrathoracic blood vessels Superior and inferior thyroid arteries

Retrosternal goiter presents with dyspnoea, stridor, and dilated neck veins. Pemberton’s sign (venous congestion of the neck on the raising of hands above the head) is seen.  

Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the neck is performed to assess the location of the thyroid. The definitive treatment is surgical excision of the ectopic thyroid.

Other options:

Option B & C: Median sternotomy (via chest) is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goiter
  • Malignant retrosternal goiter
  • Very large retrosternal goiter
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about retrosternal goitre?

choices.text: Operated in all patients regardless of symptoms
Sternal incision is always required to operate
It receives blood supply from the thoracodorsal artery
Most of the retrosternal goitres can be removed by a neck incision

questions.solution:
Most of the retrosternal goiters can be removed by neck incision (transcervical approach).

Retrosternal goitre is defined as having >50% of the goiter below the suprasternal notch. It can be either primary or secondary.

  • Primary: rare and arises from ectopic thyroid tissue in the mediastinum; receives blood supply from intrathoracic blood vessels. It is not related to thyroid tissue in the neck.
  • Secondary: they are the most common type; an extension of enlarged thyroid from the neck, usually arising from the lower pole of nodular goitre. It receives its blood supply from superior and inferior thyroid vessels.

The majority of patients are asymptomatic or have minimal symptoms. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms. Pemberton sign can be positive (facial flushing and dilatation of cervical veins upon raising the arms above the head).

CECT neck and thorax is the investigation of choice.

Over 95% of retrosternal goiters can be removed via a transcervical incision since they are an extension from thyroid tissue in the neck.

Other options:

Option A: Surgical removal of the retrosternal goiter is indicated in patients with significant airway compression, and in young patients who have symptoms such as dyspnoea or dysphagia. 

Option B: Median sternotomy approach is indicated in:

  • Primary mediastinal goiter
  • Malignant retrosternal goitre
  • Very large retrosternal goiter
  • Recurrence in the mediastinum

For a primary mediastinal goiter whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumor are properly ligated. Removing the tumor through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. 

Option C: Blood supply to the retrosternal goiter is from the thyroid vessels (secondary retrosternal goiter).

questions.text: Which of the following patients with thyroid swellings is least likely to require surgery?

choices.text: A 22 year old woman with FNAC report of Bethesda category IV
A 66 year old man with a positive Pemberton’s sign
A 58 year old man with an FNAC report of Thy2
A 16 year old girl with recurrence of thyroid cyst

questions.solution:
FNAC report of Thy2 i.e. non-neoplastic is not an indication for surgery. 

Indications for surgical management of thyroid swellings include:

  • Neoplasia: FNAC positive Thy3–5 and clinical suspicion
    • Age
    • Male sex
    • Hard texture
    • Fixity
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Recurrent cyst
  • Toxic adenoma
  • Pressure symptoms
  • Cosmesis
  • Patient’s wishes

questions.text: Pick from the following the usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy:

choices.text: Rough handling of thyroid during surgery

questions.solution:
The usual cause of thyroid storm in thyroidectomy is inadequate patient preparation before surgery. Patient preparation pre-operatively involves ensuring a euthyroid state.

Rough handling of the thyroid in thyroidectomy does not cause a thyroid storm. Though a significant amount of thyroglobulin is stored in the acinar cells, they are inactive unless converted to thyroxine (T3 and T4). 

Related Pearl: Thyroid storm / Thyrotoxic crisis:

It is an emergency caused by an acute exacerbation of hyperthyroidism. 

Precipitating factors:

  • When a thyrotoxic patient has been inadequately prepared for thyroidectomy
  • Abrupt cessation of antithyroid medications
  • Stress
    • Infection
    • Thyroid or non-thyroid surgery
    • Trauma in patients with untreated thyrotoxicosis
  • Acute iodine load
    • Amiodarone administration 
    • Exposure to iodinated contrast agents
    • Following RAI therapy

Clinical features:

  • Fever
  • Tachycardia
  • Altered mentation (delirium, psychosis, coma)
  • GI symptoms (nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea)
  • Atrial fibrillation and cardiac failure - most common causes of death

questions.text: A patient with toxic adenoma is being prepared for surgery. Which of the following statements is wrong regarding this?

choices.text: Iodine may be given pre-operatively with carbimazole
Beta blockers administered pre-operatively must be continued post operatively
Nadolol is given in a once daily regimen pre-operatively
The last dose of carbimazole must be given 24 hours before surgery

questions.solution:
The last dose of carbimazole may be given the evening before surgery.

Toxic adenoma is a benign functioning thyroid tumour, which usually presents as a toxic solitary nodule. It is an autonomously functioning tumour that does not respond to TSH. Treatment involves antithyroid drugs or radioactive iodine. This is followed by hemithyroidectomy as the surrounding normal thyroid tissue regains normal function.

Traditional preparation of a thyrotoxic patient aims to make the patient biochemically euthyroid. There are two methods of preparation that can be used:

  1. Carbimazole 30-40 mg per day is the drug of choice. When euthyroid (after 8-12 weeks), the dose may be reduced. Beta-blockers, if used preoperatively, must be given on the morning of surgery and continued for a week post-op.
  2. Propranolol 40 mg TDS or a longer-acting nadolol 160 mg once daily may be given to achieve beta-blockade. It is important to continue treatment up to 7 days postoperatively.

Iodine may be given with carbimazole or a beta-blocker 10 days before the operation. It produces transient remission and reduces thyroid vascularity.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man was posted for Hartley-Dunhill procedure. What is done in this procedure?

choices.text: Total resection of lobes on one side, with partial resection on the other side
Partial resection of each lobe removing the bulk of the gland
Total resection of one lobe with partial resection of three lobes
Resection of two lobes with the removal of the isthmus

questions.solution:
Hartley Dunhill procedure involves total lobectomy on the affected side with sub total resection on the less affected side. 

Indication: Asymmetrical multinodular goiters especially in older patients.  

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: You are performing thyroidectomy in a patient with thyroid neoplasia. Where will you make the Kocher's incision?
questions.solution:
The structures marked as "A" and "B" in the above image are thyroid cartilage and cricoid cartilage respectively. A Kocher transverse collar incision is typically 3 to 5 cm in length and is placed parallel to a natural skin crease 1 cm below the cricoid cartilage, which is marked as "B".

Rose position is preferred for thyroid surgery. The patient is supine with a towel roll below the shoulder to enable neck extension of 30 degrees. The advantage is a blood-less field as there is decreased venous congestion. However, there is an increased risk of air embolism.

Related Pearl: Thyroid Surgeries

  • Lobectomy - One entire thyroid lobe is removed.
  • Hemithyroidectomy - Total lobectomy of one lobe +isthmusectomy
  • Subtotal thyroidectomy - 2 x subtotal lobectomy (Leaving greater than 1 g of thyroid tissue on each lobe)+ isthmusectomy
  • Near total thyroidectomy - Total lobectomy but leaving less than 1 g of tissue adjacent to the RLN at the ligament of Berry on one lobe + isthmusectomy (also known as Hartley-Dunhill procedure)
  • Total thyroidectomy - 2 x total lobectomy + isthmusectomy

questions.text: At which of the following points is the recurrent laryngeal nerve at the highest risk for injury during thyroid surgery?

choices.text: At the level of Berry's ligament as it enters the larynx
In the tracheoesophageal groove as it forms one side of the Beahrs triangle
Under the tubercle of Zuckerkandl on the posterolateral portion of the gland
As the nerve loops around the aorta

questions.solution:
The point at which the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is at the highest risk for injury during thyroid surgery is at its entry point into the larynx. This point is at the cricothyroid joint, at the level of Berry's ligament.

The recurrent laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. On the left, it recurs over the arch of aorta, and on the right over the subclavian artery.

Beahrs' triangle or recurrent laryngeal nerve triangle is formed by:

  • Common carotid artery
  • Inferior thyroid arteries
  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve

Note: On the left side, the nerve has more distance in which to reach the transesophageal groove. Hence it runs in a medial plane. On the right, there is less distance and the nerve runs more obliquely to reach the groove.

questions.text: In the post-op recovery room, a patient who had undergone a thyroidectomy suddenly experienced dyspnea with stridor. He was immediately sent back to the OT. What is the most likely cause for the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Development of a hematoma post-thyroidectomy may lead to venous edema of the larynx. This can cause airway obstruction and respiratory distress. It is evacuated promptly at bedside or through surgical re-exploration.

Complications of thyroidectomy:

  • Haemorrhage - most common complication overall
  • Nerve injury 
    • External laryngeal nerve - hoarseness (more common)
    • Recurrent laryngeal nerve - hoarseness if unilateral, life-threatening aspiration and aphonia if bilateral
  • Respiratory obstruction
    • Laryngeal edema - most common cause of respiratory obstruction
    • Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
    • Laryngomalacia
    • Tension hematoma
  • Hypoparathyroidism - infarction of parathyroids
  • Thyroid storm - inadequately prepared for surgery
  • Hypothyroidism
  • Recurrent thyrotoxicosis
  • Wound infection, stitch granuloma, keloid 

Option C: Venous embolism typically occurs after a prolonged period of immobilization.

questions.text: A patient who had undergone a retro-oesophagal goitre resection was found to have partial ptosis and loss of hemifacial sweating. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Horner's syndrome. 

The cervical sympathetic trunk is at risk of injury in invasive thyroid cancers and retro-esophageal goitres and may result in Horner's syndrome. 

Related Pearl: Horner's syndrome

Horner's Syndrome:

Horner's syndrome occurring due to occulo-sympathetic paresis is characterized by the classic triad of:

  • Mild ptosis (due to paralysis of Muller's muscle).
  • Miosis (due to paralysis of dilator pupillae).
  • Reduced ipsilateral sweating (anhydrosis).

Other features include:

  • Mild enophthalmos,
  • Loss of cilio-spinal reflex,
  • Heterochromia, i.e., the ipsilateral iris is lighter in colour,
  • Pupil is slow to dilate, and there occurs slight elevation of lower eyelid.

Cocaine test (2% to 4%): Small pupils fail to dilate in Horner's syndrome.

In congenital Horner's syndrome, the additional features seen are heterochromia iridis and unilateral straight hair.
